The **inferior vena cava** (or **IVC**) is a large vein that carries
deoxygenated [blood](/wiki/Blood "Blood") from the lower and middle body into
the [right atrium](/wiki/Right_atrium "Right atrium") of the
[heart](/wiki/Heart "Heart"). Its walls are rigid and has valves so the blood
does not flow down via [gravity](/wiki/Gravity "Gravity"). It is formed by the
joining of the right and the left [common iliac veins](/wiki/Common_iliac_vein
"Common iliac vein"), usually at the level of the fifth [lumbar
vertebra](/wiki/Lumbar_vertebra "Lumbar vertebra").

The inferior vena cava is the lower
("[inferior](/wiki/Anatomical_terms_of_location#Superior_and_inferior
"Anatomical terms of location")") of the two [venae cavae](/wiki/Venae_cavae
"Venae cavae"), the two large [veins](/wiki/Vein "Vein") that carry
deoxygenated [blood](/wiki/Blood "Blood") from the body: the inferior vena
cava carries blood from the lower half of the body whilst the [superior vena
cava](/wiki/Superior_vena_cava "Superior vena cava") carries blood from the
upper half of the body.

It is a large [retroperitoneal](/wiki/Retroperitoneal "Retroperitoneal") vein
that lies [posterior](/wiki/Posterior_\(anatomy\) "Posterior \(anatomy\)") to
the [abdominal cavity](/wiki/Abdominal_cavity "Abdominal cavity") and runs
along the right side of the [vertebral column](/wiki/Vertebral_column
"Vertebral column"). It enters the right atrium at the lower right, back side
of the heart. The name derives from [Latin](/wiki/Latin_language "Latin
language"): _vena, "vein", cavus, "hollow"_.

##
Structure[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Inferior_vena_cava&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Structure")]

The inferior vena cava is formed by the joining of the left and right [common
iliac veins](/wiki/Common_iliac_vein "Common iliac vein") and brings collected
blood into the [right atrium](/wiki/Right_atrium "Right atrium") of the heart.
It also [joins](/wiki/Anastomosis "Anastomosis") with the [azygos
vein](/wiki/Azygos_vein "Azygos vein") (which runs on the right side of the
vertebral column) and venous [plexuses](/wiki/Plexus "Plexus") next to the
[spinal cord](/wiki/Spinal_cord "Spinal cord").

The inferior vena cava begins as the left and right common iliac veins behind
the [abdomen](/wiki/Abdomen "Abdomen") unite, at about the level of
[L5](/wiki/Lumbar_vertebra "Lumbar vertebra"). It passes through the [thoracic
diaphragm](/wiki/Thoracic_diaphragm "Thoracic diaphragm") at the [caval
opening](/wiki/Caval_opening "Caval opening") at the level of
[T8](/wiki/Thoracic_vertebra "Thoracic vertebra").

###
Tributaries[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Inferior_vena_cava&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Tributaries")]

The specific levels of the tributaries are as follows:

**Level** | **Vein**  
---|---  
T8 | [hepatic veins](/wiki/Hepatic_veins "Hepatic veins"), [inferior phrenic vein](/wiki/Inferior_phrenic_vein "Inferior phrenic vein")  
L1 | right [suprarenal vein](/wiki/Suprarenal_vein "Suprarenal vein"), [renal veins](/wiki/Renal_veins "Renal veins")  
L2 | right [gonadal vein](/wiki/Gonadal_vein "Gonadal vein")  
L1–L5 | [lumbar veins](/wiki/Lumbar_veins "Lumbar veins")  
L5 | [common iliac veins](/wiki/Common_iliac_veins "Common iliac veins")  
  
Because the inferior vena cava is located to the right of the midline,
drainage of the tributaries is not always symmetrical. On the right, the
[gonadal veins](/wiki/Gonadal_vein "Gonadal vein") and [suprarenal
veins](/wiki/Suprarenal_vein "Suprarenal vein") drain into the inferior vena
cava directly. On the left, they drain into the [renal vein](/wiki/Renal_vein
"Renal vein") which in turn drains into the inferior vena cava. By contrast,
all the [lumbar veins](/wiki/Lumbar_veins "Lumbar veins") and [hepatic
veins](/wiki/Hepatic_veins "Hepatic veins") usually drain directly into the
inferior vena cava.

###
Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Inferior_vena_cava&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Development")]

In the [embryo](/wiki/Embryo "Embryo"), the inferior vena cava and right
atrium are separated by the [valve of the inferior vena
cava](/wiki/Valve_of_the_inferior_vena_cava "Valve of the inferior vena
cava"), also known as the _Eustachian valve_. In the adult, this valve
typically has totally regressed or remains as a small fold of
[endocardium](/wiki/Endocardium "Endocardium").[1]

###
Variation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Inferior_vena_cava&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Variation")]

Rarely, the inferior vena cava may vary in its size and position. In
[transposition of the great
arteries](/wiki/Transposition_of_the_great_arteries "Transposition of the
great arteries") the inferior vena cava may lie on the left. It may be
replaced by two vessels beneath the level of the renal veins.[2]

## Function[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Inferior_vena_cava&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Function")]

The inferior vena cava is a [vein](/wiki/Vein "Vein"). It carries deoxygenated
blood from the lower half of the body to the [right atrium](/wiki/Right_atrium
"Right atrium") of the [heart](/wiki/Heart "Heart").[2]

The corresponding vein that carries deoxygenated blood from the upper half of
the body is the [superior vena cava](/wiki/Superior_vena_cava "Superior vena
cava").

## Clinical
significance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Inferior_vena_cava&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Clinical significance")]

Health problems attributed to the IVC are most often associated with it being
compressed (ruptures are rare because it has a low
[intraluminal](/wiki/Lumen_\(anatomy\) "Lumen \(anatomy\)")
[pressure](/wiki/Pressure "Pressure")). Typical sources of external pressure
are an enlarged [aorta](/wiki/Aorta "Aorta") ([abdominal aortic
aneurysm](/wiki/Abdominal_aortic_aneurysm "Abdominal aortic aneurysm")), the
[gravid](/wiki/Pregnant "Pregnant") [uterus](/wiki/Uterus "Uterus")
([aortocaval compression syndrome](/wiki/Aortocaval_compression_syndrome
"Aortocaval compression syndrome")) and abdominal maligancies, such as
[colorectal cancer](/wiki/Colorectal_cancer "Colorectal cancer"), [renal cell
carcinoma](/wiki/Renal_cell_carcinoma "Renal cell carcinoma") and [ovarian
cancer](/wiki/Ovarian_cancer "Ovarian cancer"). Since the inferior vena cava
is primarily a right-sided structure, unconscious pregnant women should be
turned on to their left side (the [recovery position](/wiki/Recovery_position
"Recovery position")), to relieve pressure on it and facilitate venous return
{{citation needed}}. In rare cases, straining associated with
[defecation](/wiki/Defecation "Defecation") can lead to restricted blood flow
through the IVC and result in [syncope](/wiki/Fainting "Fainting")
(fainting).[3]

Blockage of the inferior vena cava is rare, and is treated urgently as a life-
threatening condition. It is associated with [deep vein
thrombosis](/wiki/Deep_vein_thrombosis "Deep vein thrombosis"), [IVC
filters](/wiki/IVC_filter "IVC filter"), [liver
transplantation](/wiki/Liver_transplantation "Liver transplantation") and
[surgical procedures](/wiki/Surgical_procedures "Surgical procedures") such as
the insertion of a [catheter](/wiki/Catheter "Catheter") in the [femoral
vein](/wiki/Femoral_vein "Femoral vein") in the [groin](/wiki/Groin
"Groin").[4]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Major_Veins.png/220px-
Major_Veins.png)](/wiki/File:Major_Veins.png)

[](/wiki/File:Major_Veins.png "Enlarge")

Branches of Inferior Vena Cava

Trauma to the vena cava is usually fatal as unstoppable [excessive blood
loss](/wiki/Exsanguination "Exsanguination") occurs.
